English is full of all sorts of

I'm going to tell you about an English
idiom and an English proverb related to

one thing milk first of all the idiom is
to milk something in its usual form the

sentence milks something refers to
obtaining milk from an animal you milk a

cow you milk a goat however as an idiom
to milk something means to make more of

an event or situation than is reasonable
for example you have a slight cold but

you insist on being treated as if you
have something really serious wrong with

you you want to get as much attention as
possible and take advantage of the

situation oh I feel so ill could you
make me a nice sandwich I feel too weak

to do it myself be careful you might end
up being accused of milking the slight

cold you have so as to get more
attention than is necessary

normally when something bad happens to
someone we will show a certain amount of

to be careful not to milk that kindness

to take advantage of someone over a
period of time can also be referred to

as milking this often relates to the
misuse of trust and money he was milking

the company accounts for many months
before being caught

there is also a proverb in English that
